section.title: Loading configurations
section.para: Configurations are loaded by a ConfigurationLoader. The loader should immediately create a Configuration object, and then can be used to add more confiration properties to the configuration object, ie properties cannot be added the Configuration object directly. Properties can loaded via the ConfigurationLoader either from files, via Properties object, or as key-value pairs. When files are loaded they can be specified, via the addConfigurationFile(file name, ensure loaded) method, as mandatory or optional. If mandatory then the file must exist.
Although properties can be accessed from the Configuration object at any point, it should be remembered that the properties that it contains only include properties that have been loaded so far.

The default property loader (ConfigurationDefaultLoader) reads the file nakedobjects.properties from the directory config. The directory can be changed by specifying it as the parameter of the single parameter constructor. This loader uses Java style property files of the form

chapter.title: Remoting
chapter.para: Naked Objects allows remote clients to interact with a server by passing requests over a communication for another VM to deal with instead of user's VM as would happen in the standalone version. Each request starts by passing over authentication details to ensure the user is valid and to allow request to be authorised (altough requests are never passed from the client when the client knows it is not authorised, this guards against malicious access). Following that is the data for the request and here references are passed (using the Oid class) for persistent object, while graphs of data are passed for transient objects.

Requests are routed to the ServerFacade object, where each specific request results in a calls to a specific method. For example a find request goes to the findInstances method while a change to an objects property goes to the setAssociation method. The facade then decodes the parameters of the request into objectst that Naked Objects can deal with. So, for example, an IdentityData is used to look up a persistent instance, while a identifier string is used to find a NakedObjectMember. With the details of the request converted to Naked Objects objects the requisite call is made into the Naked Objects system. After that call is made two things are returned to the client, this time by converting Naked Objects objects to transferable data objects. First, the result of the call into Naked objects is return and, second, any changes made to any objects involved (the object changed set) are passed back for the client to update the objects that it has.

sect1.title: Creating a web-app
sect1.para: From the same set of project files we can create a war file for running Naked Objects on a web server such as Tomcat. Running Ant again with the web-app target will create war file in the dist directory. It is important to note that we do not need to provide and additional files or configurations to create the war.

sect2.title: Persistor
sect2.para: Ignored if type is client.

The persistor option allows you to choose how the objects created by the system will be persisted so they are still available the next time you run the system. The following options are available with the current distribution, and if none is specified then the in-memory persistor will be used for exploration mode and xml persistor will be used for other non-client modes by default.
in-memory - A simple non-persisting mechanism that will only hold the persisted object while the virtual machine is running. This is used for testing and demonstrating.
xml - A simple file based mechanism that encodes each object's data in an XML file. Alongside the data files for the objects are instance lists listing all the files for each type of object.
sql - A simple JDBC based mechanism that creates basic tables for each object type and uses these to store the object's data.
hibernate - Interface to Hibernate ORM, allowing automatic persistence of an entire DOM with the power and flexibility that Hibernate provides.
<class name> - By specifying a class name the boot loader will load up that class as the persistor.

sect2.title: Viewer
sect2.para: Ignored if type is server.

The viewer option allows you to choose the user interface that is used to access your Naked Objects application. The following options are available with the current distribution, and if none is specified then the drag and drop view will be used by default.
dnd - Drag and Drop viewer
cli - Console based Command Line Interface
cli-awt -Command Line Interface running via a basic Java AWT window
web - Web browser viewer - accessed via standard web browser such as FireFox, Internet Explorer or Opera
<class name> - By specifying a class name the boot loader will load up that class as the viewer

chapter.title: User profiles
chapter.para: Information about a user of the system (rather that a user of the application domain model) is stored in a UserProfile object which is got from the UserProfileService, which in turn is accessible from NakedObjectSession. There is also convienence methods on NakedObjectsContext to get both the UserProfile and the UserProfileService. The user profile details the perspectives the user has set up and options that have been specified, typically for the user interfaces. The user profile service provides a way to create, save and retrieve the user profiles, specifically the profile of the current user. The service in turn has a UserProfilePersistor that is used to do the actual persistence.

Profiles can be created at start up by creating UserProfileFixture subclasses. Theses are only ever loaded once as the fixture installer checks with UserProfileSevice.isInitialized() to see if the service is already set up. The profile fixture (which is defined in the application library and is therefore not part of the Naked Objects framework) loads the profiles into Naked Objects by passing in an implementation of ProfilePersistor that provides a way for the perspective to make requests of the framework.

chapter.title: Working with the Hibernate Object Store
chapter.para: In this section we look at how to store domain objects in a database using the Hibernate Object Store (HOS). Some knowledge of Hibernate is expected.
The code used throughout this section can be found in the Naked Objects distribution download in the examples directory: examples/expenses. To run the examples execute the following command:
All the other examples may also be run this way.

The HSQLDB database is used to store the data under the tmp directory. If you wish to see what data has been loaded to the database, you can run the HSQLDB database manager using the following code. This tool can list the tables and their columns, and you can run SQL commands to query the tables. If you wish to reset the database to start again then simply delete this directory.

sect1.title: Configuring the system to work with Hibernate
sect1.para: The first step is to configure the HOS. This uses a configuration file hibernate.properties, as well as the normal nakedobjects.properties, and is loaded from the ClassPath. In addition, an optional logging.properties file may also be present. In order to automatically map your domain objects to a database schema, nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.auto must be true, and the entity (domain) classes must be listed under nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.classes. To see a full list of available properties, and their possible values see the section on Hibernate Object Store Properties.
sect1.programlisting:
# turn on automatic mapping of Naked Objects to Hibernate nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.auto = true # drop/recreate on setup nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.schema-export = true # Hibernate type used to map List and InternalCollection. Allowed values list/bag nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.list = bag # map collections as one-to-many or many-to-many? Allowed values one/many nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.collections = one # assume relationships are bidirectional - i.e. map with inverse="true" nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.assumeBidirectional = true # shutdown the DB - required for Derby, useful for HSQL as it compacts the files nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.shutdown = true
# classes which Hibernate must auto map nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.classes = \ org.nakedobjects.object.application.BasicApplicationContext \ , org.nakedobjects.object.application.SimpleUser \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.defaults.Claim \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.defaults.Employee \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.defaults.ExpenseType \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.defaults.Item \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.defaults.TemplateClaim \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.Airfare \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.CarRental \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.GeneralExpense \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.Hotel \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.Journey \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.Meal \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.MobilePhone \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.PrivateCarJourney \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.Taxi \ , org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.item.Train
nakedobjects.services.prefix = \ org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.resources.hibernate nakedobjects.services = HibernateClaimRepository \ , HibernateEmployeeRepository \ , HibernateExpenseTypeRepository \ , HibernateItemRepository
nakedobjects.fixtures.prefix = \ org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.fixture nakedobjects.fixtures = ExpenseTypes, Employees \ , RichardPsExpenses, Context, CurrentUser
sect1.para: Note that nakedobjects.services is still required to specify which resources are loaded, but now we use Hibernate specific implementations. We will cover these later.

sect1.title: Managing Hibernate Mapping Files
sect1.para: There are a number of options for creating and managing Hibernate mapping files within the naked objects framework.

sect2.title: Automatic
sect2.para: Allow Hibernate to auto-generate the mapping files. These will then be stored in the export directory and reused each time the application is started. They can be regenerated either by deleting the mapping files from their export directory or by setting the regenerate flag.

sect2.title: Manual
sect2.para: Write the mapping files manually. They can then be placed in the export directory, or elsewhere on the classpath, and identified within the hibernate.cfg.xml file with a mapping tag (see below).

sect2.title: Customised
sect2.para: Allow Hibernate to auto generate the mapping files and then optimise these by hand.

For both manual and customised files care should be taken not to set the regenerate flag if the files are being picked up from the export directory as they will be overwritten by new auto generated files.

sect1.title: Configuration options for Hibernate
sect1.para: The Hibernate configuration uses the normal hibernate.cfg.xml file. This configures the database engine to use the specified file to store the database while running as an integral part of Naked Objects (that is: not as a separate process).
sect1.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?> <!DOCTYPE hibernate-configuration PUBLIC "-//Hibernate/Hibernate Configuration DTD 3.0//EN" "http://hibernate.sourceforge.net/hibernate-configuration-3.0.dtd"> <hibernate-configuration> <session-factory> <property name="bytecode.use_reflection_optimizer">true</property>
<property name="connection.driver_class">org.hsqldb.jdbcDriver</property> <property name="connection.username">sa</property> <property name="connection.password"></property> <property name="connection.url">jdbc:hsqldb:file:tmp/hsql-db</property> <property name="dialect">org.hibernate.dialect.HSQLDialect</property>
<property name="current_session_context_class"> org.hibernate.context.ThreadLocalSessionContext </property>
<property name="connection.provider_class"> org.hibernate.connection.C3P0ConnectionProvider </property> <property name="hibernate.c3p0.minSize">3</property> <property name="hibernate.c3p0.timeout">1000</property> </session-factory> </hibernate-configuration>
sect1.para: If any entities are to be mapped without using the HOS automatic mapping then they should be specified here using <mapping> tags, and a separate hbm.xml file created to define the mapping. You can also change the JDBC connection provider, or specify any other Hibernate configuration here, if required.
The HOS requires that the current_session_context_class property must be left as org.hibernate.context.ThreadLocalSessionContext.

sect2.title: Connection Pooling
sect2.para: C3po is used for connection pooling. When used with Hibernate c3po has two sets of configuration. The first within the hibernate.cfg.xml file. E.g.
And the second within the c3po.properties file. For example, these settings will help debug connection closure problems.

The c3po.properties file is optional as are all the c3po properties within hibernate.cfg.xml. Both files should be on the classpath, with the hibernate.cfg.xml file specifically in the resources directory. All properties default to values as described in the c3po documentation. As your project approaches the deployment phase, c3po settings should be tuned for the particular configuration the system is running on.

sect1.title: Writing Hibernate repositories
sect1.para: In the early stages of prototyping a domain model, it is common practice to use 'naive' implementations of repositories, that operate with all objects in memory. Subsequently, the prototype may be run with the HOS, in which case it is appropriate to replace some or all of those repository implementations with Hibernate-specific implementations, which use the power of the Hibernate Query Language and the database to perform queries. For the expenses prototype four Repositories were created under org.nakedobjects.example.expenses.resources.naive. These classes provide simple implementations for retrieving objects by looping through all instances of a class, and comparing values (using an implementation of the provided Filter interface).
For example, in NaiveEmployeeRepository the method to find an Employee by name is
Whereas the implementation for HOS in HibernateEmployeeRepository uses a Hibernate Query to perform the same function.

HOS provides a class to simplify creating repositories, org.nakedobjects.nos.store.hibernate.service.hibernate.service.H ibernateFactoryAndRepository. These are based on the standard AbstractFactoryAndRepository but provide additional helper methods to find objects using a query string, a Hibernate Query, or Hibernate Criteria. It also provides methods to create a Hibernate Query or Criteria.
Useful methods are:

listitem.para: find...() - there are a multitude of find()methods. Some take a text query, others a Hibernate Query or Criteria (which can be created by one of the following methods).
createCriteria(final Class cls) - create a Hibernate Criteria for cls.
createEntityQuery(final String whereClause, final Class cls) - create a Hibernate Query for cls, with the specified where clause.

createCountQuery(final String whereClause, final Class cls) - create a count(*) Hibernate Query for cls, with the specified where clause. These queries should be executed directly, or passed to countNotZero(final Query query) to check if the returned count is not zero.
createQuery(final String query) - create a Hibernate Query from a complete query string.
findFirst..() - follows the same pattern as the find() methods, except it will only return the first object returned from the query.

sect1.para: When using Hibernate Queries or Criteria, they should first be created using one of the create() methods, any parameters should be set, and then the populated Query or Criteria can be passed to one of the find() methods to return the required objects.

Note: where Hibernate Queries are created for the passed-in cls parameter, and only a where clause is specified, then the alias of the object is "o", i.e. the generated query starts "from org.nakedobjects.ClassName as o"

If required, the Hibernate Session can also be obtained by calling getSession(), which also ensures that there is an active transaction running. The Session can then be used to create Queries or Criteria, which can then be passed to one of the find() methods. HOS will ensure the transaction is committed at the end of the NOF transaction.

sect1.title: Coding requirements for domain objects
sect1.para: When coding with Hibernate there are a few rules to follow for each domain class you wish to persist:

sect2.title: Provide a no-argument constructor
sect2.para: The HOS requires that there is a no-argument constructor for each domain class. Java provides an implicit no-argument constructor, unless you have implemented a constructor with arguments, in which case you must provide an explicit no-argument constructor as well. Note, however, that it is not considered good practice within Naked Objects to use constructors at all - because objects created via constructors are unknown to the application container. If you need to create a new object within your application code, you should use the newTransientInstance() or newPersistentInstance(), which are provided on the DomainObjectContainer or on AbstractDomainObject.

sect2.title: Provide an identifier property (optional)
sect2.para: Hibernate requires an identifier property for each persistent entity. If no identifier property is specified for an entity then the HOS will generate one automatically, but it will be managed internally within Naked Objects and not be visible either to users or to the application programmer. If you wish to have programmatic access to the identifier then you need to add an identifier property, which must be called id.

sect2.title: Provide a title property (optional)
sect2.para: The HOS will automatically, persist the object's title, based on the title() method, or toString(), to enable searching by title.

sect2.title: Prefer non-final classes
sect2.para: Final classes can't be lazy-loaded by Hibernate, so final classes cause a performance overhead. (Refer to Hibernate documentation for further information).

sect2.title: Declare accessors and mutators for persistent fields (optional)
sect2.para: Within Naked Objects an accessor (or 'getter') is mandatory for any field which is to be made available to the user, and a mutator ('setter') is required, except for collections.
Hibernate recommends accessing ALL persistent fields (including collections) using both an accessor and a mutator. When using HOS you have two options:

listitem.para: use field access by setting the nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.valueFieldAccess and nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.associationFieldAccess properties

create get() and set() methods for all persistent fields, including collections. By following the Naked Objects coding style you should already have these for all value and object properties These methods may be private or protected.

sect2.title: Avoid accessor/mutator pairs on interfaces when auto generating mapping files.
sect2.para: The hibernate mapping generation code in Naked Objects may bring interfaces into the mapping class hierarchy. If this happens it will try to access any field identified by standard bean accessor/mutator methods (i.e. get<Field> and set<Field>) on the interface. Since this field does not exist on the interface this will cause an error. Typically this won't happen as interfaces are not included in the hierarchy - but it's best to avoid anyway as changes to the class hierarchy may bring interfaces in, in a non-obvious way. Not having both methods or renaming them will avoid this issue.

sect2.title: Collections
sect2.para: Collections must be declared using the interface type, e.g. java.util.List rather than a concrete type such as java.util.ArrayList. Currently List is the only supported collection type within Naked Objects, however you may also use arrays.

sect2.title: Version and Modification properties (optional)
sect2.para: For every domain object, Naked Objects creates a version number, as well as modified by user and time, and associates this with the object internally. The HOS will create additional columns on the database to hold this information, as needed by the framework. If you wish to have this information explicitly accessible as properties on your objects you need to add the following properties in hibernate.properties:

listitem.para: nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.version for the name of the version number property. This must be a java.lang.Long.
nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.modified_by for the userid of the last person to modify an object. This should be a string.
nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.modified_on for the date the object was last updated. This should be a java.util.Date

sect2.para: Note: these are system wide values, so if you use this feature you must use a consistent naming scheme across your objects.

Each of these values is optional. By default these properties are accessed using the setting of nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.valueFieldAccess. To specify a different access mechanism, each of these properties has an associated .access property, for example nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.version.access. This can be set to the Hibernate access type, namely field, property or ClassName.

sect1.title: Specifying Hibernate for persistence
sect1.para: The above examples provide basic persistence via a file based (XML) persistence layer. To use a persistence layer based on Hibernate a small amount of configuration is required. First copy across the Hibernate configuration file - hibernate.cfg.xml - from the distribution's resource directory. In its newly copied state this file specifies that the database is HSQLDB, but it does contain other configurations that can be uncommented so you can use other databases such as MySQL or SQLServer.

The only other task is to list the classes that need to be mapped to database tables so that object store can set up the database and create the Hibernate mappings for you. This list need only name the root objects as any reachable class will also be mapped. This can be added to the nakedobjects.properties file. Alternatively a new file, hibernate.properties, may be added to the config directory, which will only be loaded when the Hibernate persistor is used. The following properties setting registers two classes that are to be persisted using Hibernate.

To run Naked Objects with the Hibernate persistor change the persistor type to hibernate when starting up Naked Objects. The following shows the integrated web server from above being run with the Hibernate persistor.

During start up the Hibernate persistor will generate Hibernate mapping files and add them to a newly created directory called mappings. Assuming that you used the default configuration in hibernate.cfg.xml the HSQLDB engine will be used and a directory, hsql, will be created to contain the files. For more information see Working with the Hibernate Object Store.

chapter.title: Recognised Methods (Prior to Java 1.5)
chapter.para: If you are not using Java 1.5 then the methods in this section can be used instead of the annotations described in the next section. Note that not all annotations have a non-Java-1.5 equivalent.

sect1.title: Field order
sect1.para: An order for the fields can specified via a method with the field order method.
The method should return a comma separated list of field names (which are case and space insensitive) with the names listed in the order they should be used.

sect1.title: Action order
sect1.para: An order for the action can specified via a method with the action order method.

The method should return a comma separated list of action names (which are case and space insensitive) with the names listed in the order they should be used. Actions can be grouped together by surrounding the group with brackets ('(' and ')') and prefixing the group with name and colon, e.g. "(group name: first name, second name, etc)".

sect1.title: Descriptive controls
sect1.para: Field and action names are normally derived from the name of the method, but this can be changed. Also descriptions and help text can be provided from within the domain classes. The following signatures are recognised and used to get a name, description or help text for fields or actions.
The parameters in an action can be labeled as a complete set.
sect1.programlisting: public static String[] names<actionName>([<parameter type> param]...)

sect1.title: Static controls
sect1.para: Specific fields can be hidden from the user; they are deemed to be internal to the object.
sect1.programlisting: public static boolean alwaysHide<fieldName>([<field type> param])
sect1.para: Fields and action parameters can be flagged as required, so that the object is not valid, or the action cannot be invoked until the field/parameters are set.
sect1.programlisting:
public static boolean optional<fieldName>(<field type> param)
public static boolean[] optional<actionName>([<parameter type> param]...)

sect1.title: Hibernate Object Store Properties
sect1.para: The behaviour of the Hibernate Object Store can be tailored using properties as detailed below. All properties have a common root of nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.

By default, when running with command line option -r hibernate properties are loaded from configuration nakedobjects.properties, hibernate.properties and logging.properties which are located on the classpath. All examples are given using standard Java.

sect2.title: Automatic mapping
sect2.para: To automatically map Naked Objects as persistent Hibernate entities auto property must be set.
Once generated the mapping files will be reused each time the application is started unless the regenerate property is set. Which will force the mapping files to be regenerated each time
Mapping files are written and read from the location (under the application root) given in the hbm-export property.

sect2.title: Specifying mapped persistent classes
sect2.para: The list of persistent classes which will be automatically mapped is specified by the classes property. Any related entity classes in each class's hierarchy will be automatically picked up as necessary, however it is preferred to explicitly list all persistent classes.
As a shortcut you can specify the prefix for all classes listed in the classes property using classes.prefix.
sect2.programlisting: nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.classes.prefix = \ org.nakedobjects.example.ecs nakedobjects.persistence.hibernate.classes = Customer, Location \ , City, Telephone, CreditCard, resources.ReferenceGenerator

sect2.title: Checking if the Object Store is initialized
sect2.para: Fixtures are run, and the database tables created, only when an Object Store is not initialized. By default the HOS is defined to be initialized if any of the mapped tables exists, with the specific table selected at random from the classes mapped to the database.
This behaviour can be overridden is several ways.
To explicitly specify if the HOS is initialized set the initialized property.

To allow the Object Store to determine if it is initialized by checking the existence of a specific table then you can specify the catalog, schema and table using the initialized.catalog, initialized.schema and initialized.tableproperties. Depending on your database, only initialized.table is required.

sect2.title: Creating database tables
sect2.para: Hibernate contains tools which can be used to create the database schema. If the Object Store is not initialized (see above), and the schema-export property is set, then the database tables are created automatically using the Hibernate SchemaExport tool.

sect2.title: Updating the database schema
sect2.para: If the HOS is initialized (see above) the database schema can be updated automatically to keep in line with any changes to the domain model. This functionality is used the Hibernate SchemaUpdate tool, and is specified by setting the schema-update property. Current limitations of this tool should be checked from Hibernate documentation.

sect2.title: Save/update/delete behaviour
sect2.para: Within NOF, save, update and delete requests are stored within a NOF transaction, and only submitted to the database at the end of the NOF transaction. This can obviously cause issues, for example when looking up an object in the database that was saved during the same session. Therefore, by default the Hibernate Object Store executes save/update/deletes as necessary (typically triggered by queries). To revert to normal NOF behaviour set the saveImmediate property to false.

sect2.title: Database shutdown
sect2.para: Some databases require certain routines to be run when the application shuts down. To specify that this occurs set the shutdown property to true.
At Naked Objects shutdown, this has the following effects for the specified databases:

listitem.para: HSQLDB: runs the SHUTDOWN COMPACT SQL command to correctly organise and compact the database.

sect2.title: List behaviour
sect2.para: By default any persistent collections of type java.util.List are mapped using Hibernate bag semantics, that is to say that list order is not preserved. In order to change behaviour set the list property to list. This will change the mapping to use Hibernate list semantics, and will generate a position column on the database. The default setting is bag.

sect2.title: Collection behaviour
sect2.para: By default persistent collections are modelled using a one-to-many association. Hibernate maps this type of association by linking the tables of two classes via a foreign key, with no intervening collection table. Hibernate can also map collections as many-to-many associations, which requires a dedicated collection table. In order to map collections using many-to-many associations set the collections property to many. The default setting is one.

sect2.title: Property or field access
sect2.para: Hibernate has alternative strategies for accessing properties of persistent entities. By default all properties are accessed using Hibernate's property access method, that is to say via get() and set() methods. In a Naked Objects system, when Hibernate loads or saves an object this will mean getters will call resolve() and setters objectChanged(). The Hibernate Object Store will ignore these calls, but obviously this does cause some overhead. In order to access the fields directly, and so bypass the getters and setters, Hibernate also provides a field access method. There are two properties to use, set valueFieldAccess for Hibernate to access values and relationships to single objects directly, and associationFieldAccess for Hibernate to access collections directly.

Note: if you set either of these properties then you must ensure that the field names in your object match the property names, i.e. String xxx; and getXxx(). sect2.title: Bidirectional associations
sect2.para: You can tell the Hibernate Object Store to assume that a bidirectional relationship between two Naked Objects, that is where the association can be navigated in both directions, should be mapped as a bidirectional Hibernate association. This will only occur in the following circumstances: for Naked Objects A and B, A must have one and only one association to B, and B have one and only one association to A.
By setting property assumeBidirectional entities will be mapped using inverse="true" in Hibernate terms.

sect2.title: Changing column names
sect2.para: By default properties are mapped to columns of the same name. This may cause database errors if properties have the same name as a database reserved word (although the mapping code will attempt to preempt collisions by renaming columns that have the same name as a database keyword), or you may simply wish to map a property to a different column. sect2.title: Version and modified information
sect2.para: NOF holds version and modification information externally to an object. This is especially important for client-server set ups. However, using HOS it is also possible to hold this information as properties of a Naked Object. To specify which properties match the NOF version/modified data you can specify 3 properties, whose values are the property names on your object:

listitem.para: version for version number. This must be a java.lang.Long.
modified_by for the userid of the last person to modify an object. This should be a string.
modified_on for the date the object was last updated. This should be a java.util.Date

sect2.para: Note: these are system wide values, so to use this feature you must use a consistent naming scheme across your objects. By default these properties are accessed using the setting of valueFieldAccess above. To specify a different access mechanism, each of these properties has an associated .access property, for example version.access. This can be set to the Hibernate access type, namely field, property or ClassName.
